items.title: Alumni Shoutout
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Alumni Shoutout! "@JahFlor_ is a family farm in Vieques, Puerto Rico run by husband and wife duo D'Andre Smith and Jahzara Heredia. We collaborate with our neighbors, educators, and grassroots organizations to support the local movement for food justice and sovereignty. As farmers, we are working towards a solution to the inequity that imperialism has created on this island. Before the US Navy seized two-thirds of the island to use as military testing grounds, Vieques had a robust agricultural industry. Today there is a huge demand for fresh foods. Health is so critical on this island that suffered environmental pollution during its brutal history of military occupation. The absence of a hospital in Vieques is an injustice and a big source of pain in the community. Many people have died from treatable diseases. Women have little choice but to leave the island to give birth. We see increased access to fresh foods and herbs as a step towards healing and prevention. Our goal is to become a reliable and accessible source of vegetables, herbs, and flowers for Vieques. Join us on our journey to cultivate resilience and healing within our community by supporting us on Patreon! www.patreon.com/JahFlor “Farming is our way of taking back our power.” - Jahzara Heredia, Co-founder, Farm Manager, 2018 BFLI 2.0

items.title: Keeping SEEDS is an act of TRUELOVE for our ANCEST…
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Keeping SEEDS is an act of TRUELOVE for our ANCESTORS and our collective FUTURE! ~ @TrueLoveSeeds. Passing on the exquisite illustrations of farmer/artist Jasmine Hamilton @artbyjasminehamilton for True Love Seeds African Diaspora Seed Collection. Soul Fire Farm began our relationship with @TrueLoveSeeds @Seedkeeping to pass on the legacy of our ancestral crops and more. We cultivate and keep the Plate de Haiti Tomato seed, which is featured in one of these glorious cards. The seed packets and the postcards feature powerful seed stories: 1. Plate de Haiti Tomato, Marie-Jeanne Lamartiniére, and the Haitian Revolution, grown by Soul Fire Farm. @soulfirefarm 2. 1. Mississippi Silver Hull Crowder Pea and Ms. Geneva Clay Newsome, grown by Sankofa Community Farm. @sankofacommunityfarm 3. Paul Robeson Tomato and Paul Robeson, grown by Truelove Seeds. 4. Buena Mulata Pepper and Horace Pippin, grown by Truelove Seeds. The African Diaspora Collection Seed Packets and Postcards are now available in the Print Shop at www.trueloveseeds.com. As always, each purchase of these seeds directly supports the work of these amazing growers, as well as to QTBIPOC Philadelphians through a care package curated by @manyfortunes in collaboration with @asianartsphilly. ABOUT THE ARTIST Jasmine Carolyn Hamilton is an African American Queer visual artist. She works as painter, illustrator, and sculptor based in Philadelphia by way of her hometown of East Chicago, Indiana. and content reposted with love from @Seedkeeping

items.title: TONIGHT 2/25/21 starting at 4:00 PM EST, join the …
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

TONIGHT 2/25/21 starting at 4:00 PM EST, join the conversation by YES! Magazine's: An Ecological Civilization: The Path We're On. This event features contributors to the upcoming issue of YES! Magazine, "An Ecological Civilization"—Vandana Shiva, Leah Penniman, Winona LaDuke, and Jeremy Lent—and will be facilitated by YES! executive editor Zenobia Jeffries Warfield and Andrew Schwartz, co-founder and executive vice president of the Institute for Ecological Civilization. Head to the link in our bio to reserve your seat!

items.title: We are kicking off this year’s 3D Virtual Skill-sh…
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

We are kicking off this year’s 3D Virtual Skill-share series with a visionary workshop guided by SFF Co-Director Larisa Jacobson and Rock Steady Farmer (@rocksteadyfarm ) Amara Ullari (@mishi_amara) on March 11 from 3:00 PM EST-4:30 PM EST. We are invoking the quiet and stillness that the winter offers to guide us in reflection, dreaming, and planning for how our upcoming growing season will flourish. This visionary practice is what we call crop planning, a process that paints a big picture idea of what we will be growing over the season and then breaks it down to the details of how we will achieve our goals to ensure an abundant season. This interactive virtual skill share is designed for BIPOC and features Spanish interpretation. Amara (@mishi_amara) also shares their Crop Planning brilliance in our forthcoming Liberation on Land Video coming soon! Available free for everyone. Head to the link in our bio to register!

items.title: Seeds are synonymous with hope
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Seeds are synonymous with hope. They carry within their tiny shells all of the DNA needed to bloom and nourish our bodies and spirits. Whether the seeds you plant are literal or figurative, they are planted with an intention and a vivid vision of the future; there is an inherent trust that as long as the seed is placed with love, watered, and tended to it will sprout, grow, and flourish into something beautiful. Our ancestors braided seeds into their hair before boarding the transatlantic slave ships because they knew that hope could brave the journey to these strange new lands and spark motivation in the hearts of their loved ones, despite such devastating tragedy and loss. There is legacy in seeds. We began our relationship with @TrueLoveSeeds @Seedkeeping in so that we could save and pass on ancestral crops that have been cultivated for centuries and that we now grow here at the farm. We cultivate and keep the Plate de Haiti Tomato seed, Scotch Bonnet pepper, Bee Balm Sweet Annie, and Calendula. Naima and Emet harvesting calendula flowers for our tea An abundance of Calendula seeds harvested by Naima, Raei, Brooke, Z, and Emet! Brooke, Raei, and Z admiring the magnificence of the Calendula seeds Plate de Haiti Tomatoes growing in the West Field high tunnel Plate de Haiti Tomato seeds saved from the 2020 season separating from the pulp Scotch Bonnet peppers in the West Field high tunnel Bright and beautiful bee balm before it has gone to seed Vibrant Sweet Annie thriving in the summer

items.title: BLACK LEGACIES // BLACK FUTURES
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

BLACK LEGACIES // BLACK FUTURES "The time has come now when we are going to have to get what we need ourselves. We may need a little help, here and there but in the main, we're going to do it ourselves." Fannie Lou Hamer Farmer, singer, and dauntless Civil Rights activist, Fannie Lou Hamer was born in 1917, the granddaughter of enslaved Africans and the daughter of sharecroppers east of the Mississippi Delta. As the youngest of 20 children, she was forced to the fields at age 6 to pick cotton on the plantation. She later worked as the plantation's record keeper, keeping official records of how many bales sharecroppers had picked. She realized that the plantation owner had been adjusting the scales to increase his profit, so Hamer set the scales right. In that act alone she became an activist and later said, "I didn't know what to do and all I could do is rebel in the only way I could rebel." Fannie Lou Hamer founded the Freedom Farm Cooperative in 1969 on 40 acres of prime delta land with a goal of empowering Black farmers and sharecroppers. The co-op consisted of 1,500 families who planted cash crops, as well as mixed vegetables. Together, they purchased another 640 acres and started a "pig bank" that distributed livestock to Black farmers. Back in 2005, when we started dreaming up Soul Fire Farm, we asked ourselves, what would it be like to start a farm for the people based on this legacy, based on the challenge that Fannie Lou Hamer put forth to us saying, “When you’ve got 400 quarts of greens and gumbo soup canned for the winter, nobody can push you around or tell you what to say or do.” This idea that to be truly free, we need to feed ourselves, became the basis of the work at Soul Fire Farm. Thank you Fannie Lou Hamer for your relentless struggle for freedom for our people.

items.title: The Ecological Landscape Alliance presents a day l…
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

The Ecological Landscape Alliance presents a day long virtual conference on Wednesday March 3rd from 9:00 AM - 3:00 PM EST called Landscapes in Transition - Building Resilience: Landscaped for Now and the Future. From 10:15-11:15am join Leah Penniman to learn about Farming While Black: African Diasporic Wisdom for Farming and Food Justice. This presentation will explore strategies for increasing the carbon storage capacity of soil, including adding biochar, both for increasing carbon and infiltration capacities; restoring degraded and eroded lands through planting; and mulching.  Head to the link in our bio to purchase tickets for the conference.

items.title: Friday, March 5th we are joined by Yemi Amu of Oko…
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Friday, March 5th we are joined by Yemi Amu of Oko Farms @okofarms who will discuss aquaponics, urban farming, and healing the climate. ASK A SISTA FARMER - Are you ready to grow your own food and medicine for self-reliance and community resilience? First Fridays, experienced Black womxn* farmers answer your call-in questions about gardening, livestock, agroforestry, plant medicine, business operations, and food preservation. At the end of the show we have a GIVEAWAY to the person who wins our quiz. To free ourselves we must feed ourselves! Join us by heading to the link in our bio! **Ask A Sista Farmer centers the voices of Black, Indigenous, People-of-Color, Queer, Trans*, Disabled, Immigrant, and Poor communities. Everyone is welcome to watch and listen, but please make space for centered folks to share. Thank you. **Sista and womxn includes trans* and nonbinary folks *Photos reposted from @okofarms

items.title: The Mohican Nation: "People of the waters that are…
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

The Mohican Nation: "People of the waters that are never still." Sharing our stories, people to people, is such an important part of sovereignty work. Heather Bruegl from the Mohican nation presented to our team about the history and legacy of the Stockbridge Munsee Mohican people. As people not indigenous to the land we inhabit, it has been integral that we explore the ways we can be accountable to the land’s original stewards. Part of our relationship building process has been establishing a cultural respect easement that gives Mohican citizens the legal right to use Soul Fire land for ceremony and wildcrafting whenever they please in perpetuity. As in years past, all proceeds of our seed sales are remitted to the Mohican nation for their cultural work. We remain committed to ongoing solidarity with and accountability to the Mohican community. If you know anyone from the Mohican Nation, check out the flyer in the images - help them share their stories! Also pictured are beautiful ears of Mohican corn. The corn was planted in the Stockbridge-Munsee Mohican style, as requested by Warren Mihtukwsun, "The corn is planted in mounds. The mounds are about 32" wide and 2 ft. tall. The Sturgeon and sucker run is always in the Spring. In the Spring we spear the suckers and put them in the mounds. This might be hard to replicate, but chicken bones, eggshells and/or compost could be put in the mounds if desired. Plant 12-13 corn seeds per mound, starting at the bottom of the mound and planting each seed "from pinkie to thumb distance" apart. If desired, plant beans "around the outskirts of the mound" at the same time as the corn. Some mounds could have sunflowers planted on them instead of corn." We are saving this seed and sharing with our Stockbridge Munsee Mohican friends in Wisconsin.

March 10 from 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM EST. Head to the link in our bio to sign up! @naimainfinity

items.title: Each One, Teach One
items.content_html:
@soulfirefarm

Each One, Teach One. Many Hands Make Light Work. Volunteer with us at Soul Fire Farm to learn about some of our farming practices while supporting our work and getting your hands on the land. During our first Work and Learn Days (April 1st, April 6th, April 8th, April 13th) participants will collaborate with Soul Fire team members on mulching beds, planting lowbush blueberries, planting trees, and spreading compost. Registration required. IMPORTANT: Due to the pandemic we are limiting work-and-learn days to those residing in New York State or bordering states of NJ, CT, PA, MA & VT. If you are not coming from these states we kindly ask you participate in a virtual program instead. See all of our programs by visiting the link in our bio! Please only register if you are able to stay for the entire day as spots are limited. Given the decreased capacity of our programs during COVID, we ask that you kindly limit your registration to ONE community farm day. Your consideration and generosity ensures accessibility to this healing time on the land to as many people as possible! Check out some pics from last year’s mulching and compost spreading days! Head to the link in our bio to register!

items.title: To my fellow visual humans, you might feel me when…
items.content_html:
@swissmiss

To my fellow visual humans, you might feel me when I say: I hate TVs. That black rectangle that most humans arrange their living space around. That’s why I am a big fan of projectors. They hide away. They are subtle. (The new short throw projector by VAVA is great!) But when you have a wall that is flooded with direct sun light, all day long, projectors don’t work. I researched alternatives and found Le Frame from Samsung. A TV that is mounted flush to the wall and looks like a big piece of art when not in use. The brain of the tv is stowed away underneath in the tv console (which by the way is by @castleryus). Le Frame was designed by fellow Swiss industrial designer @yvesbehar and I can wholeheartedly say I have never been more excited about a gadget. The entire product experience is excellent. (With the exception of opening the remote to put batteries in. I had to YouTube it to see if someone had some tips! And sure enough, a kind soul explained the trick!) The joy it brings me to change the art is unmatched. Creating a home that is visually pleasing is my happy place. And yes, I acknowledge, I am lucky I have the finances to do so. (Ps: This is not a sponsored post. I genuinely love sharing products I love. I have been doing so for 15+ over on my blog. Swiss-miss.com)

items.title: Today my son turned 11
items.content_html:
@swissmiss

Today my son turned 11. A few thoughts on the day: Photo 1: It sucks to have a birthday during a pandemic. Especially when you are a kid. Streamers outside your house telling everyone in the neighborhood it’s your birthday makes it a little better. Photo 2: Cats dig balloons. Who knew!? Video 3: Given the pandemic birthday nature, I wanted to create something special and decided to hang a gaggle of love notes above Tilo’s bed. Each of them describes something I love about him. Will he roll his eyes or approve? Photo 4: Success! It resonated. He had a *huge* smile on his face and said “this is sooo cool!” Photo 5: May this be his first and last pandemic birthday. Maybe it helps to know that 11, 22, 33, 44, 55, 66... are considered lucky birthdays in Switzerland. We call them “Schnapszahl birthdays”. Aka “Schnaps number” as in seeing double. I love you, Tilo!

items.title: Slow Tina, slow
items.content_html:
@swissmiss

Slow Tina, slow. These ski slope markers were seemingly talking to my subconscious these past few days. It’s my kids’ winter break and I took three days off to go skiing upstate, in search of some normalcy and pursuit of joy. (My kids have been couped up at home for almost a full year now, remote schooling.) Besides being nervous on how this would all work in regards to Covid safety, I am in the middle of a work Tsunami, making it difficult to be fully present. I found myself waking up in the wee hours, mind racing, and trying to get a few hours of work in before everyone wakes up. I had entrepreneurial parents growing up and as a kid, didn’t understand why they would be talking about work or being on the phone with their staff during vacation. (No email or Slack back then!) I get it now. I wish Catamount, the ski area, would put Ram Dass’s words “Be Here Now” on the side of the slopes as well, just like the SLOW markers. I bet I am not the only one who could use the reminder. Being *fully* present, no matter what is happening in your life, is a practice. Some days I can do it. Some days I can’t. Here’s to learning and growing. Ps: The second photo is my little family, including ex-husband. We amicably divorced and love skiing together. This makes me happy.

items.title: My favorite part of the holidays was my Milly Aunt…
items.content_html:
@sohlae

My favorite part of the holidays was my Milly Auntie’s saltine bark, loaded with milk chocolate and salted peanuts! This tostada toffee is inspired by her bark and @rick_andrew_martinez great new @food52 show SWEET HEAT 🌶 Broken tostadas are doused in a spicy/sweet toffee and loaded up with all sorts of toasty and chewy toppings! Watch our Freaky Friday moment where we swap cookies (and shows) at the link above!

items.title: I teamed up with @hbomax to create a dish inspired…
items.content_html:
@sohlae

I teamed up with @hbomax to create a dish inspired by one of my favorite shows, HBO’s Game of Thrones! Remember when Arya was all about that revenge life and surprised Walder Frey with a pie made of his SONS?? This Sons of Frey Savory Meat Pie is inspired by that unforgettable moment—but made appetizing with short ribs braised in chicken bone broth (double meat!) and stained blood-red with roasted beets️It's topped with a flaky pie crust and baked until golden brown and bubbly I like to eat it while rewatching that scene, then maybe skipping back to watch Arya take Ser Meryn's eyes, or ahead to when she fakes out the Night King ❄ With HBO Max, I can stream all the titles I love from any of my devices! Head to the link above to sign up today!

items.title: I’ve never been more excited to see a video
items.content_html:
@sohlae

I’ve never been more excited to see a video! While @hamegram and I were shocked we could even make a wall stand up, @seth.bakes and @priyakrishna were building a masterpiece and the @nytcooking team captured it all! Most of 2020 may have been one giant turd, but I’m so happy it led to this, I’ve never had more fun on a shoot and feel so lucky to call this my job! Thanks to @scottloitsch @vaughn @emofly and @ginadelaselva for all your very hard work making this happen and letting us break in the brand new nyt kitchen! Head to the NYT Cooking YouTube channel to watch the full video, link in bio

items.title: This year had been tough for so many for so many r…
items.content_html:
@sohlae

This year had been tough for so many for so many reasons, but I’m trying to be grateful for the good. 2020 is the year I learned to know my worth, and it’s not just about getting paid fairly. My opinions and ideas deserve respect, and so do yours. As a woc I’ve always been expected to be grateful for any opportunity, take what’s given to me without question, and stay quiet. That’s not only expected of woc, but anyone who doesn’t fit a very narrow idea of what a leader should look like. Fuck that. Don’t let anyone shut out your ideas because they think you’re not thin enough or rich enough or straight enough or white enough or man enough. That’s not me anymore. Thank you for all of your support. You lifted me up just when I was ready to give up and I hope I can share that energy with others in 2021. Cheers to a New Year and let’s keep pushing!

items.title: I remember when meant pound, not hashtag
items.content_html:
@sohlae

I remember when meant pound, not hashtag. Back when there were landlines and *69? So... I want to call this okay? Make sure you take care of the details: start with room temperature ingredients to create a stable emulsion, cream the butter and sugar until fluff-city, and stop the mixer to scrape down the paddle and the bowl. If you do all that this base vanilla batter can take on anything, from a few extra folds for mix-ins like chopped dates or blueberries, flavors like matcha or lemon zest, or swirls of cocoa and streusel like my black and white variation above! Head over to @food52 to learn my go-to, super tender, unfaltering recipe then take it off-script and make it all your own! Thanks to @emmalaperruque for the expert editing and @gabriellamm @fakattack and @wonbowoo for turning my tried ramblings into a video!

items.title: Want saucy, glossy, sticky, crispy, spicy chicken …
items.content_html:
@sohlae

Want saucy, glossy, sticky, crispy, spicy chicken wings? Head to the link above to learn my method for brined and roasted chicken wings, then take the recipe off-script to make it your own! For the glassiest skin, be sure to dry brine the wings in salt, sugar, msg, and baking powder for 24 hours A two-temperature roast is key to rendering out all of the fat (flabby wings are not welcome here) then caramelizing the sauce 🌶Make a punchy glaze with acid, heat, and sweet to cut the richness of the chicken Photo by @fakattack

Do you like history? Do you like food? (Of course, you do. That's why you're here!) Then check out my new series on the HISTORY YouTube channel, Ancient Recipes with Sohla every Saturday at noon! Each week, we'll dig up a recipe from the past and see how it does in the now! In this week's episode, I try to bake an ancient pizza recipe on a shield🛡Will it pizza??? Tune in to find out! And don’t miss a new episode of Sunday at 9/8c on The HISTORY Channel!
